poem:
**The Overlooked Chords**

In Liverpool's shadowed glow,  
where strings spun silent dreams,  
the girls strummed songs unsung,  
their chords a secret river.  
Beneath the Beatles' soaring fame,  
their amplifiers whispered  
a melody of might,  
a tremolo of untold stories.  
Girls that played, guitars alight,  
unfurling notes in the twilight.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Girls Don’t Play Guitars review – Liverbirds musical is just ho-hum Despite being one of the world’s first all-female rock groups, electrifying concerts in the UK, Europe and the world during the 1960s, the Liverbirds and their legacy have been dwarfed by that of fellow Liverpool band the Beatles. Ian Salmon musical Girls Don’t Play Guitars attempts to make their case. A guitar outline encircles centre stage, lassoing the girls – tearaway Val (Molly-Grace Cutler),". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
